newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia creates fund for aged care bonds.
newsitem.headline: Australia creates fund for aged care bonds.

text.p: The Australian government on Wednesday announced a new fund to invest and administer accommodation bonds paid by the elderly to hostels and other aged care providers.
Family Services Minister Judi Moylan said a single, national independent trust would be created to handle the bonds, which are paid by the elderly for entry into aged care facilities.
Annual income earned by the fund would reach about A$130 million within three to four years and A$1.5 billion within a decade, Moylan said in a statement.
Income from the fund would be returned to nursing homes and hostels to help maintain and upgrade facilities.
"The fund will be professionally managed under the supervision of a board which will include members from banking, legal and provider backgrounds," Moylan said.
Hostels and nursing homes would have to join the fund, or an alternative approved prudential scheme, in order to be allowed to charge bonds from October 1.
The new fund would guarantee the security of residents' bonds, Moylan said.
